comments:
No data in the method statistics view when attaching to the Java profiling 
agent in enabled mode.

The same problem exists event when the JIT is disabled.

Instructions to reproduce:

1. Launch HeapJdniCarTest in enabled mode:
	java -classpath . -XrunpiAgent:server=enabled HeapJniCarTest

2. Attach and start monitoring HeapJniCarTest.  ENSURE that the "Show instance-
level information" check box IS checked on the Profiling Options window.
3. Perform a heap dump by clicking the 'Collect object references' button
4. Press enter until the program terminates
5. Open the method statistics view and verify that no data is present in the 
view.

I get an exception:

Exception in thread "main" java.lang.NoClassDefFoundError: Engine
        at HeapJniCarTest.<init>(HeapJniCarTest.java:38)
        at HeapJniCarTest.main(HeapJniCarTest.java:48)

Paul, did you select the Execution Time Analysis profiling type? The method 
statistics view shows execution times for methods, and will only be present if 
that type is enabled. Collecting object references won't affect this view, as 
it's not related to memory.

Curtis, can you please make sure we have the proper options send to RAC, I 
think we are. Assuming we have the correct options sent, the RAC doesn't seem 
to send us the methodDef information, by profile to file and look into the 
profile file.

Confirmed. I get no data at all. Trace file does not contain any method 
entries/exits. Investigating further..

Marius, can you see whether the loaders are receiving any data from the RAC? My 
trace file's XML seems to be incomplete (no closing TRACE tag) when I profile 
to a file.

Created an attachment (id=10021)
profile file (not zipped)

This seems to be a profiler problem. The trace doesn't contain any methodDef, 
methodEntry or methodExit events.

Isn't this exactly what's expected? The last step of the test case says:

5. Open the method statistics view and verify that no data is present in the 
view.

There is no data, as expected... .  (In particular, no data has even be collected.) 

The reason this is the case is because the user attaches to the program after
the first (and only) method entry takes place (in the main method). After
attaching, the profiler will only receive notification of the method exit event
of the main method, but we cannot print this out to the trace since we never saw
the method entry. Unless other method entry/exit pairs take place between the
time you've attached and the time the program terminates, you won't see anything
in the method stats view.

Confirmed as invalid.  This defect was due to an old test class.

Bullet 5 refers the verifying the test to reproduce to this defect, hence no 
data in the method statistics view.
